confession.devil_appearance: man in black on black horse
confession.seduction_date: about 6 years after first husband's execution (approximately 1600)
confession.seduction_context: In despair because of execution of first husband and her poverty. Decided to take her child and go around country begging; as she approached Nancy she met man in black on black horse. Offered to give her money if she would serve him, and when she said she would not do this if it was for any harm promised her it was not.
sabbat_activities: ate black bread, black meat, black salt
drank water that seemed like wine but tasted bad

timeline.subject: Jacqueline Manouvrier
timeline.details: Initial interrogation where she confessed to bewitching daughter of Chrestofle Arnoult, attending sabbat, and using divination

timeline.subject: Jacqueline Manouvrier
timeline.details: PG (C.M. Rémy) asks for death sentence after confrontations with those she has accused

timeline.subject: Jacqueline Manouvrier
timeline.details: Sentence approved by Change de Nancy

timeline.subject: Jacqueline Manouvrier
timeline.details: Formal death sentence from court at St Nicolas

accomplices_named.name: widow of Nicolas Piccard
accomplices_named.context: Recognized at sabbat by her large hands and her coat. Said that she would have enough grain.

accomplices_named.name: wife of Humbert Vaulthier
accomplices_named.context: Seen at sabbat. Husband is chartier (carter) of St Nicolas.

accomplices_named.name: beggar (who normally wore a white hat)
accomplices_named.context: Seen at sabbat. Had been chased out of Remereville on suspicion of witchcraft.

accomplices_named.name: wife of beggar with white hat
accomplices_named.context: Seen at sabbat. Had been chased out of Remereville on suspicion of witchcraft.

accomplices_named.name: big man with a 'rochat'
accomplices_named.context: Seen at sabbat. Father of 'la passementiere'.

accomplices_named.name: wife of Mre Jean Simon
accomplices_named.context: Seen at sabbat. Husband is schoolmaster of St Nicolas.

accomplices_named.name: Jehanne Patteate
accomplices_named.context: Seen at sabbat. Aunt of la Gueriatte.

accomplices_named.name: la Remenderesse of rue des Estuves
accomplices_named.context: Seen at sabbat. Mother-in-law of Simon Gallois, chartier.

notable_quotes.speaker: Jacqueline Manouvrier
notable_quotes.french: A dict estre la verité qu'ayant eu quelque querelle avec lesdits Arnoult et sa femme pour se venger de ce elle print d'une pouldre que le malin esprit luy avoit baillé, et en espandit au porche de la maison dudit Arnoult a intention de rendre sa fille en extremité de maladie et dequoy elle fut perclue de ses membres.
notable_quotes.english: Said it was true that having had some quarrel with said Arnoult and his wife, to avenge herself she took some powder that the evil spirit had given her, and spread it on the porch of said Arnoult's house with the intention of making his daughter extremely ill and rendering her limbs paralyzed.

notable_quotes.speaker: Jacqueline Manouvrier
notable_quotes.french: A dict que deux mois apres qu'elle eust donné ledit mal elle fut visiter ladite malade et esmeue de compasion de la veoir ainsy tourmentée et de crainte qu'elle avoit d'estre accusée elle feit un pottage luy feit manger, puis apres la frotta avec de l'huille provenante du couvent des Peres Ambrosiens, et usa d'une pouldre blanche que luy avoit esté donnée par ledit malin esprit, ce qu'ayant faict commença ladite pauvre malade a recuperer sa santé.
notable_quotes.english: Said that two months after she had given said illness she went to visit said sick person and moved by compassion to see her thus tormented and from fear that she would be accused she made a pottage and made her eat it, then after rubbed her with oil from the convent of the Ambrosian Fathers, and used a white powder that had been given to her by said evil spirit, which having done said poor sick person began to recover her health.
notable_quotes.context: Confession to healing the girl she had bewitched

notable_quotes.speaker: Jacqueline Manouvrier
notable_quotes.french: A dict estre la verité qu'ordinairement estante advertie de la maladie de quelques enfans elle prenoit une serviette, et en la mesurante avec le bras Invocquant plusieurs Saincts en apres conseilloit aux peres et meres desdits enfans d'aller en pellerinage en plusieurs lieux
notable_quotes.english: Said it was true that ordinarily being informed of the illness of some children she took a napkin, and measuring it with her arm invoking several Saints, after advised the fathers and mothers of said children to go on pilgrimage to several places
notable_quotes.context: Confession to divination practices for diagnosing illness

relationships.evidence_text: daughter of Nicolas Manouvrier and his wife Justienne
First husband was Urbain Lamouleur, who had been hung about 15 years before
married to Didier Martin, cordonnier, for 12 years
accusing her of bewitching one of her daughters
wife of Humbert Vaulthier, chartier of St Nicolas
wife of Mre Jean Simon, schoolmaster of St Nicolas
Jehanne Patteate, aunt of la Gueriatte

relationships.person1: la Remenderesse of rue des Estuves
relationships.evidence_text: la Remenderesse of rue des Estuves, mother-in-law of Simon Gallois, chartier

economic_context.details: Jacqueline was in poverty after first husband's execution, leading to begging. This poverty was explicitly cited as context for her seduction by the devil. Money given by devil turned to oak leaves. No children by second marriage.

harms_catalog.harm_description: extreme illness, limbs paralyzed (perclue de ses membres)
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: quelque querelle avec lesdits Arnoult et sa femme
harms_catalog.method_alleged: black powder spread on porch of Arnoult's house

material_culture.context: Three types of magical powder given by devil: black to kill, unspecified to make languish, white to heal
Made pottage for sick girl as part of healing

material_culture.object: l'huille provenante du couvent des Peres Ambrosiens (oil from Ambrosian Fathers convent)
material_culture.context: Used to rub sick girl during healing
Used for divination by measuring with arm while invoking saints
Devil's money turned into oak leaves
Took holy water in church despite devil trying to prevent her
Devil rode black horse when he met Jacqueline
Worn by beggar from Rozieres who attended sabbat
Widow of Nicolas Piccard recognized by her coat at sabbat
Worn by big man at sabbat

spatial_references.context: Location of trial, residence of accused and many accomplices
Jacqueline was approaching Nancy when she met the devil
Location of 3 accomplices seen at sabbat
Beggar and wife had been chased out on suspicion of witchcraft

spatial_references.place_name: porche de la maison dudit Arnoult
spatial_references.context: Where Jacqueline spread powder to bewitch daughter
Source of oil used in healing
Where Jacqueline took holy water despite devil's attempts to prevent her
Where witches gathered to dance, eat, and plan crop damage

economic_hardship_indicators: poor people at sabbat opposed ruining grain crop

emotional_state_notes: moved by compassion to see sick girl tormented

third_parties.name: Urbain Lamouleur
third_parties.context: First husband, hanged about 15 years before trial (c. 1594). His execution and resulting poverty led to her seduction by devil.

third_parties.name: Chrestofle Arnoult Cuieffre
third_parties.context: Husband of formal accuser, father of bewitched daughter

third_parties.name: daughter of Arnoult (bewitched)
third_parties.context: Made extremely ill with paralyzed limbs for 2 months, then healed by Jacqueline

third_parties.name: child of Jacqueline
third_parties.context: Child from first marriage, with her when begging and met devil, died of smallpox 18 months after her seduction

third_parties.name: widow of Nicolas Piccard
third_parties.context: Seen at sabbat, recognized by large hands and coat

third_parties.name: Humbert Vaulthier
third_parties.context: Chartier (carter) of St Nicolas, husband of accomplice

third_parties.name: Mre Jean Simon
third_parties.context: Schoolmaster of St Nicolas, husband of accomplice

third_parties.name: la passementiere
third_parties.context: Daughter of big man with rochat who attended sabbat

extraction_metadata.notes: This is a confession-based trial with no witness testimony recorded in the document. The trial moved very quickly from interrogation (Aug 7) to death sentence (Aug 29). Jacqueline confessed voluntarily without torture, including detailed accounts of sabbat attendance and bewitchment. Notable that she: 1) admitted both harming and healing the same victim, 2) practiced divination/cunning folk practices using napkin measuring and saint invocations, 3) repeatedly opposed crop damage at sabbat (claiming poor people didn't want to agree), 4) continued religious practices (holy water) despite devil's opposition, 5) threw away remaining powder in river. Her poverty after first husband's execution (by hanging) is central to the seduction narrative. The formal accuser Didiere called her 'sorciere et double sorciere'. C.M. Rémy (Nicolas Rémy, author of Daemonolatreiae) was the prosecutor. Change de Nancy approved the death sentence without modification. Document does not specify execution method but given standard practice and approval process, likely strangulation then burning.
